title: Spatial scale
text:
Spatial scale is a specific application of the term <a href="Scale%20%28disambiguation%29">scale</a> for describing or categorizing (e.g. into <a href="orders%20of%20magnitude">orders of magnitude</a>) the <a href="size">size</a> of a <a href="space">space</a> (hence "spatial"), or the extent of it at which a phenomenon or process occurs.
For instance, in <a href="physics">physics</a> an object or phenomenon can be called microscopic if too small to be visible. In <a href="climatology">climatology</a>, a <a href="micro-climate">micro-climate</a> is a <a href="climate">climate</a> which might occur in a <a href="mountain">mountain</a>, <a href="valley">valley</a> or near a lake shore. In <a href="statistics">statistics</a>, a <a href="megatrend">megatrend</a> is a political, social, economical, environmental or technological <a href="Trend%20%28statistics%29">trend</a> which involves the whole <a href="planet">planet</a> or is supposed to last a very large amount of time. The concept is also used in <a href="geography">geography</a>, <a href="astronomy">astronomy</a>, and <a href="meteorology">meteorology</a>.
These divisions are somewhat arbitrary; where, on this table, "mega-" is assigned global scope, it may only apply continentally or even regionally in other contexts. The interpretations of "meso-" and "macro-" must then be adjusted accordingly.
